bioghist.p: William Wagner (1796-1885) was a philanthropist and naturalist. At the age of 16, he was apprenticed to the financier Stephen Girard. In 1816 he was sent as an assistant supercargo on a two-year trading voyage, during which he collected many shell, plant, and fossil specimens. After leaving Girard's employ, he went into business as a shipping merchant with Charles A. Snowden. This partnership was dissolved in 1825, and Wagner continued as a merchant in his own firm. He retired from business in 1840. In 1847, he began to deliver lectures on scientific topics, and, finding that interest in these lectures was strong, founded the Wagner Free Institute of Science in 1855.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of some of William Wagner's business papers. Included are financial papers, documents relating to legal matters, rental and insurance papers, business correspondence and some financial records of the Wagner Free Institute of Science. This collection includes the deed to the land on which the Institute was built.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
